summary: This is an FBI 302 report documenting an interview with Dr. [REDACTED], the Chief Psychologist at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), conducted on August 29, 2019. The interview details the psychological intake process, suicide watch protocols, and the specific psychological care and observations of Jeffrey Epstein from his intake on July 8, 2019, until his death. It includes details of a July 23 incident where Epstein was found with a loose noose, his housing concerns, and the psychologist's hypotheses about the event.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The high-profile inmate at MCC facing sex offense charges. The document details his psychological assessments, placement on suicide watch and observation, his interactions with staff, and the incident on July 23, 2019, where he was found with a loose noose.

persons.name: Dr. [REDACTED]
persons.context: The interviewee, identified as EMPLOYEE 19. She oversaw psychological services at MCC, conducted and reviewed Epstein's suicide risk assessments, made housing recommendations, and managed his psychological observation status.

persons.name: Tartaglione
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). Epstein alleged Tartaglione tried to kill him and called him a pedophile, leading to hypotheses about the July 23 incident being an assault, gaming, or a suicide rehearsal.

persons.name: Lt. [REDACTED]
persons.context: A lieutenant in the SHU. Dr. [REDACTED] passed Epstein's complaints and requests to him. He is described as very regimented.

connections.description: Dr. [REDACTED] was the chief psychologist responsible for Epstein's psychological assessments, suicide watch status, and overall mental health care during his incarceration.
They were cellmates in the SHU. Epstein reported that Tartaglione called him a pedophile and alleged Tartaglione tried to kill him, which was one hypothesis for the July 23 incident.

events.title: Epstein's Psychological Intake
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein completed the Psychological Services Intake Questionnaire (PSIQ) at MCC. He did not mark anything concerning, but due to his high-profile case and sex offense charges, Dr. [REDACTED] ordered he be placed on observation status for a thorough suicide risk assessment.

events.title: Epstein Found with Loose Noose
events.description: Epstein was found in his cell with a loose noose around his neck and was placed on Suicide Watch. He told Dr. [REDACTED] he did not remember what happened and denied suicidality. He alleged his cellmate, Tartaglione, tried to kill him.

events.title: Epstein Taken Off Suicide Watch
events.description: Dr. [REDACTED] met with Epstein, who reported being fearful of returning to his cell with Tartaglione. Epstein denied being suicidal. Dr. [REDACTED] took him off Suicide Watch and placed him on Psychological Observation.

events.title: Epstein Returned to SHU
events.description: Dr. [REDACTED] transitioned Epstein back to the Special Housing Unit (SHU) with a recommendation he be housed with a cellmate to decrease isolation and provide a rescue opportunity.

events.title: Epstein Signs New Will
events.description: The document notes that Epstein signed a new will on this date. Dr. [REDACTED] stated that had she known, it would have been considered a red flag and Epstein would have been placed on Psychological Observation.

locations: 1 Saint Andrews Plaza, New York, NY, 10007 (US Attorney's Office, Southern District of New York)
keyFacts: Epstein was subjected to three suicide risk assessments during his time at MCC, which was noted as unusual.

On July 23, 2019, Epstein was found in his cell with a loose noose; he alleged his cellmate Tartaglione tried to kill him, while staff hypothesized it could have been gaming, a suicide rehearsal, or an assault.
Dr. [REDACTED], the Chief Psychologist, was unaware Epstein had signed a new will on August 8, 2019, which she stated would have been a major red flag prompting immediate psychological observation.
The psychologist believed the lack of a cellmate for Epstein and understaffing at MCC contributed to his death.
The report indicates regular rounds by correctional officers in the SHU were not being completed, a fact executive staff like Dr. [REDACTED] were unaware of due to fear of retaliation among inmates.
